Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses

Grounds_for_Claim: Disability discrimination, Refusal to cooperate with medical assessment
Decision_Outcome: Federal Court dismissed judicial review application, upheld Commission's decision
Government_Body_or_Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court of Canada
State_Protection_Assessment: State protection found adequate; issue already addressed through grievance process
Credibility: Claim deemed vexatious; lack of evidence supporting disability-based inability to cooperate
State_Protection_Adequacy: Adequate, as existing grievance process addressed the issues

Application_Facts: Failures in managing mineral rights by the Crown, specifically related to fiduciary duties concerning mineral rights surrendered in the 1940s
Procedural_Issue: Motion for leave to amend the Statement of Claim
Decision_Outcome: Amendments allowed under Rule 201 as they arise from substantially the same facts as the original claim
Outcome: Amendments permitted; no prejudice to defendant; costs awarded appropriately
Relief_Sought: To include new particulars or causes of action in the Statement of Claim
Remedy_Sought: Leave to amend the Statement of Claim
Legal_Standard_Applied: Rule 201 of the Federal Court Rules
Decision_Rationale: The amendments are allowed because they arise from substantially the same facts as the original claim and serve the interests of justice, despite potential limitation period concerns

Application_Facts: Election invalidated due to irregularities affecting results; applicants ceased to hold office unless explicitly stated otherwise; governance gap risked
Procedural_Issue: Appeal arbitrator found irregularities; respondents moved for receiver/manager appointment
Evidence_Used: Findings of appeal arbitrator on election irregularities
Decision_Outcome: Election invalidated; applicants ceased to hold office
Remedy_Sought: Ensure proper governance until new elections
Legal_Standard_Applied: Under CER, officials cease to hold office if election is invalidated unless otherwise stated
Decision_Rationale: To maintain electoral integrity and prevent governance gap

Legal_Issue: Whether applicants remain in office after election ordered to be redone due to infractions
Evidence_Assessment: Arbitrator found infractions affecting election results
Legal_Rule: Officials hold office until appeal determines invalidity; receiver may be appointed if just or convenient
Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of harm to SRFN members due to lack of valid governance
Defendant_Response: Applicants argue they remain in office under custom
Outcome: Motion granted; Browning Crocker Inc. appointed
Legal_Provision: CER s. 3.4(b), s. 15.9.3; Federal Courts Act s. 44

Dispute_Type: Validity of SRFN Council following election irregularities
Legal_Issue: Existence of governance gap requiring receiver/manager appointment
Procedural_Stage: Post-invalidation of election; motion for interim management
Evidence_Assessment: Only three councillors remained, lacking quorum; evidence of potential misuse of funds
Legal_Rule: If election infractions materially affect results, prior results are invalidated and new election required
Grounds_for_Claim: Invalidation of election; risk of harm from continued governance by invalidated officials
Key_Evidence_Considered: Number of remaining councillors, affidavits, legal arguments
Defendant_Response: Applicants argue continuity of leadership per custom
Outcome: Motion granted; Browning Crocker Inc. appointed until new election

Dispute_Type: Governance gap due to invalidated election and fund misuse
Legal_Issue: Appointment of receiver/manager due to election invalidation under CER
Procedural_Stage: Post-invalidation of 2008 election; pre-new election phase
Evidence_Assessment: Only three councillors remained; risk of fund misuse by invalid council
Legal_Rule: CER s. 15.9.3 mandates new election if infractions affect results; s. 44 permits receiver if just or convenient
Grounds_for_Claim: Invalidation of 2008 election; need to protect band funds
Key_Evidence_Considered: Arbitrator's finding of infractions, number of remaining councillors
Outcome: Motion granted; Browning Crocker Inc. appointed until June 29, 2009 election

Crimes.Defendant_Response: Parents failed to declare children and provide supporting evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and declarative evidence
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of refusal based on misrepresentation and H&C assessment

Crimes.Application_Factor: Existence and best interests of children

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, suffered severe injuries, undergoing psychotherapy and physical therapy, had pending humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) application, sought deferral of removal on medical and humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Enforcement Officer failed to properly assess medical evidence and made unreasonable factual inferences
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer did not adequately consider submitted medical evidence
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deferral of removal based on medical and humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Removal must be executed as soon as reasonably practicable under IRPA s.48
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer made patently unreasonable findings regarding treatment availability in Fiji and failed to properly assess ongoing medical needs
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Enforcement Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada after issuance of removal order due to medical conditions and pending H&C application; requested deferral of removal
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Subject to removal order with pending H&C claim
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to failure to depart following removal order
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Officer failed to thoroughly consider medical evidence and mischaracterized treatment prospects in country of removal (Fiji)
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient consideration of medical evidence and lack of inquiry into healthcare accessibility in Fiji
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Request for deferral of removal denied
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside on judicial review; remitted for reconsideration by a different officer
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deferral of removal based on health and humanitarian considerations
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of deferral request by a new enforcement officer
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: IRPA s.48 – removal to be carried out as soon as reasonably practicable; limited discretion to defer based on exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer's conclusions about medical treatment availability in Fiji were unreasonable and based on inadequate assessment
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Enforcement Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC)

Violation_Type: Failure to meet definition of Convention refugee
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration Act - Definition of Convention refugee
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, IRPA, s. 96-98
Application_Facts: Applicant born in Russia, resided in Latvia, claimed statelessness and persecution; court found she was entitled to Russian citizenship through a simple formality (passport stamp); no evidence of persecution in Russia
Claimant_Status: Applicant seeking refugee status in Canada
Residency_Compliance: Applicant residing in Latvia, outside country of nationality (Russia)
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Refugee Board's decision
Evidence_Used: Evidence regarding eligibility for Russian citizenship, lack of proof of persecution in Russia
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence of actual persecution in Russia
Claim of statelessness not substantiated due to entitlement to Russian citizenship
Credibility_Assessment: Court found claim of statelessness unconvincing due to available access to Russian citizenship
Relief_Sought: Stay in Canada under protected status
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Board’s negative determination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under the 1951 Refugee Convention
Decision_Rationale: Applicant has effective nationality (Russia), can avail herself of state protection, and failed to demonstrate a well-founded fear of persecution

Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer breached the duty of fairness or made an unreasonable decision regarding humanitarian and compassionate exemption

Outcome_on_Merits: No breach of fairness or legal error found; officer's decision upheld
Key_Evidence_Considered: Interview with applicant, evidence on marriage authenticity, risk assessment in Northern Ireland
Legal_Framework: Canadian immigration law, administrative law principles
Defendant_Response: Officer conducted thorough interview and considered all evidence
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Authority: Immigration officer, Federal Court (on judicial review)
